article.headline: Western Michigan 97, Northwood 60
article.story: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. (AP) -- Awaiting the start of his first game since 2003, a grinning Rollie Massimino chatted with the VIPs sitting next to his team's bench. He joked with the officials, hugged players who helped him win the 1985 national championship and slapped Villanova coach Jay Wright on the rear. Then Massimino took a seat -- and stayed there for all of 10 seconds. The 71-year-old perpetual motion machine was back on the sideline Saturday night, coaching the first game for a new NAIA program at tiny Northwood University. The Seahawks lost 97-60 to Massimino's former team, Villanova. "At least Villanova won," he said with a chuckle. "It was a great evening. I got a little teary-eyed only once." Massimino coached the Wildcats to an upset victory over Georgetown in the NCAA title game 21 years ago, and they showed their appreciation by making a trip to Florida to help launch his Northwood era. Six members of the '85 Villanova team were on hand, transforming the game into a reunion as well as a grand opening. "I think they were cheering for both sides," Massimino said. It made for a lively night at the Countess de Hoernle Student Life Center, with Massimino's return from retirement drawing a noisy sellout crowd of 1,600, nearly double Northwood's enrollment. Chuck Daly, Billy Cunningham and Bobby Orr -- Massimino's golf posse -- sat in the first row next to the Northwood bench, while students stood throughout the game, chanting "air ball" and riding the refs like every other campus crowd. "It's terrific for Rollie," Daly said. "It's kind of a dream he put together over the last two years. He has made it happen, which isn't that easy. It's a credit to him. He has a lot of friends, and he's very industrious." At halftime the '85 Villanova players were introduced, and fans sang happy birthday to Massimino, who turns 72 Monday. "I'm going to deduct a year from now on," he said. The old coach's last game was at Cleveland State more than three years ago, but his persistent sideline pacing showed he hasn't lost a step. He chomped gum, screamed instructions and angrily called timeout twice in the first half as Northwood's deficit mounted. Massimino punctuated one Villanova layup by stomping his foot in disgust. But in the final minute, he was grinning again. "Everyone from Villanova has mentioned that he looks 20 years younger," said Wright, Massimino's former assistant. "This is what he loves." Daly offered the Northwood coach input during the game, while Cunningham shouted and Orr whispered in Massimino's ear. "They were all giving advice," Massimino said. "See the score? Great advice." While the Seahawks worn the same blue and white colors as Villanova, they couldn't match their opponents' quickness and speed. Northwood struggled to get the ball across midcourt against Villanova's full-court press, and the Wildcats built leads of 14-2, 31-11 and -- at halftime -- 56-29. Curtis Sumpter, returning from a knee injury that sidelined him all of last season, had 16 points and seven rebounds for Villanova (1-0). Dwayne Anderson also scored 16, while Scottie Reynolds went 6-for-6 and added 13 points. Baree Ward, who scored the Seahawks' first basket, and teammate Marvin Owens had 15 points apiece. The Seahawks committed 22 turnovers and were outrebounded 42-20. "It's a win, no matter what, because they're playing," Cunningham said. "It's wonderful for Rollie and the school. This is Rollie's passion. He wants to do this as long as he can breathe." The rest of the schedule will be less daunting for Massimino, who has lined up such opponents as Olivet Nazarene, Medicine Hat and College of the Bahamas. "I don't think we're going to play another team as good and as aggressive," Massimino said. "I hope not, anyway."

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
